9.27.17  9:35 pm   what are the two pronounced chords on the guitar 8 seconds in https://youtu.be/lcEqU4Bmo64?t=8s ?

9.27.17  12:26 pm   Hi I just asked the question about sharps, flats and naturals. I guess the altered note in one clef but not the other would never really come up because you'd just change the scale degree.. like if you had a C7#9 or whatever you'd never write the #9 note as Eb, you'd write it as D# so that way you don't have an E and Eb)...

     that's true but there are some situations when it gets really dense when you might need F and F# at the same time. let's say if you are scoring a horror movie or something you might even need them in the same octave because you have F, F#, G all mashed together. i honestly have no idea how you would notate that. it is rare and only in extremely dissonant 'horror' type situations

      but I'm not really asking you about the sharp/flat rules.. I'm more just curious about my system.

9.27.17  12:22 pm   9.27.17  12:52 am    yeah I know that Chris Farley was the one who wrote the lyrics, but are the chords that you used to to accompany the singing also his?

     no. all i had to work with was what can be heard in the movie

     btw sorry if I was messing up words, english is not my native language

     ah, right.... melody actually just means the notes he sang. not any of the chords or other notes that support

9.27.17  12:20 pm   When I write down music, I always get confused about sharps, flats and natural symbols. Like if you have a note outside of the key signature and you put a flat,sharp or natural symbol on it, by the next measure are you supposed to assume that if that same note has no symbol then it's back to normal? Or if the note is altered in one clef, but not the other, do I put a sharp/flat/natural symbol on just the one clef and leave the other one unaltered?

     in situations like that i think courtesy accidentals are very important

     What if there's a modulation, do I put the new key signature in the middle of the score, or do I just adjust the sharps and flats accordingly?

     if it stays there for a significant amount of time, then put a new key signature

     My strategy is just to write everything as if it's in the key of C.

     that is sometimes called an 'open key' and it is mainly used when it's just so all over the place it's not worth putting a key signature. i used an open key for a video where i transcribed and harmonized spoken language, as music. no sense putting a key because it was all over the place. but most 'reasonable' music should have a key signature

     Notes that are sharp I write the sharp symbol, notes that are flat I write the flat sumbol. I never write the natural symbol, and if a note is played with a sharp or flat multiple times in the same bar, I write the symbol each time (instead of just once). This works fine for me, because usually the only per son who reads my sheet music is me. And this system makes sense to me.... but is this a bad strategy if I were to share my music with other people?Like if I were to write something out for some horn players or a piano player or whatever, would this system throw them off do you think? 

     yes. accidentals last at least until the end of the bar. i always thought there was disagreement about whether or not they last until the end of the line. but they definitely last at least until the end of the bar, and you should not be repeating the symbol if the note stays that way within the same bar, and therefore you need a natural to specify if it changes back. and if it changes back right at the beginning of the next bar, probably use a courtesy natural just in case. if it's in different octaves i think the rules become a little more ambiguous and courtesies are good, i'm not sure of the exact rules when it's different octaves

9.27.17  5:41 am   If you have to perform along to a song you've heard only once, which instrumental part (vocals included) do you think you could remember the best and confidently play?

     every song is different. in many cases the drums have the least to worry about because they don't have to really learn the chord changes. however, there are many songs where drummer crucially needs advanced knowledge of the road map, breaks, hits, kicks, etc. although this is reasonably easy to memorize by counting. chord changes can be very easy to memorize if you have a large familiarity with common music, and the song is relatively normal. the vocals would usually be by far the hardest to immediately get, due to lyrics

9.27.17  4:13 am   Do you create better work when you are under strict guidelines set by someone else or when you have total freedom? 

     guidelines set by someone else does not work for me. total freedom is insane to deal with, and setting guidelines for myself is confusing and challenging. but otherwise nothing will happen and i would explode. which i did for quite some time until eventually figuring it out

     without time and space, the journey never would have existed. the song would not have existed. and you would not exist and neither would i. there are many ways to use time, and one of the best ways is by telling stories and being creative
